properties.media:imagetext:
MONEY TALKS!
When you give a tip to someone who has per-
formed a service for you, what you are saying is
"thank you." Tipping is a language understood all
over the world, although the rules about whom to
tip and how much vary from country to country.
OUR TIPPING TABLE
This easy-to-use table will give you an idea of the
amounts usually tipped in the major countries of
Europe and the Middle East. If the sums shown
seem a bit small, you may wish to give more in
appreciation of especially fine service. Americans
abroad are often apt to overtip.
As you will see in the table, hotels and restau-
rants in many countries add a service charge to
their bills. This generally amounts to 10% or 15%
of the bill. When this is done, you need only leave
some small change for an employee who per-
forms a service for you.
Some countries add a tax to the hotel bill,
such as the V.A.T. in the U.K. This should not be
confused with a service charge which may or may
not be added to the bill in addition to the tax.
EXTRA TIPS
In addition to the categories listed here, you may
also be expected to give a number of other tips.
Wine stewards in restaurants, for example, usually
receive a tip equal to 10% of the cost of the wine
you order.
Sightseeing guides are sometimes tipped in
Europe. When there is no fixed fee, tip the local
equivalent of 50¢ or more, depending upon the
TWA
length of the tour. If there is a fixed fee for the
sightseeing tour, 15% of it is the right tip for the
guide.
If you leave shoes to be shined outside the
door of your hotel room (it's the custom in
England and in many places on the Continent), be
sure to leave a tip equal to about 35¢ a night for
the porter who shines them.
One thing more: a smile accompanying your
tip is one of the very best ways to show that you
really mean to say "thank you!" It's sure to be
understood and appreciated everywhere you go.
NO TIPPING ON TWA!
I've left one category out of this list of people to be
tipped-and I'm very glad to be able to do so. You
never tip when you travel via TWA. Neither your
attentive Flight Attendant nor any of the TWA
ground personnel expects a tip or is permitted to
receive one. However, the airport porter who
carries your bag through the terminal will expect
a tip.
CONSULT THE EXPERTS
WHEN MAKING
YOUR PLANS
For help in planning a trip, selecting a tour, making
flight and hotel reservations, visit your TWA travel
agent and ask his or her advice. Or, call the TWA
Reservations number listed in your telephone
directory to consult with our experts. TWA serves
major cities across the United States and destina-
tions throughout Europe and the Middle East.
We look forward to welcoming you aboard TWA.
